title: C88-1044

sentences.text: This paper presents necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English and discusses implications for current discourse processing algorithms .
We examine a broad range of texts to show how the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions is genre dependent .
This research is part of a larger study of anaphoric expressions , the results of which will be incorporated into a natural language generation system .

Entity-this_paper.label: this paper
Entity-this_paper.description: This paper presents a study on the necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English, exploring their implications for discourse processing algorithms and analyzing their distribution across different text genres.

Entity-this_research.label: This research
Entity-this_research.description: This research refers to the investigation of necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English, which is part of a broader study on anaphoric expressions aimed at enhancing natural language generation systems.

Entity-implication_for_current_discourse.label: implications for current discourse processing algorithms
aliases: implications for current discourse processing algorithms
Entity-implication_for_current_discourse.description: The term 'implications for current discourse processing algorithms' refers to the potential effects and considerations that the findings regarding demonstrative expressions in English may have on the design and functionality of algorithms used for understanding and processing discourse in natural language processing systems.

mentions.local_name: implications for current discourse processing algorithms

Entity-necessary_and_sufficient_conditio.label: necessary and sufficient conditions
Entity-necessary_and_sufficient_conditio.description: Necessary and sufficient conditions refer to the specific criteria that must be met for the correct use of demonstrative expressions in English, as outlined in the context of discourse processing algorithms.

Entity-demonstrative_expression_in_engli.label: demonstrative expressions in English
Entity-demonstrative_expression_in_engli.description: Demonstrative expressions in English refer to linguistic elements such as 'this', 'that', 'these', and 'those' that indicate specific entities in discourse, and their usage is influenced by contextual factors and genre.

Entity-the_distribution_of_demonstrative.label: the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions
aliases: the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions
Entity-the_distribution_of_demonstrative.description: The distribution of demonstrative forms and functions refers to the varying usage patterns and roles of demonstrative expressions in English across different genres of text.

mentions.local_name: the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions

Entity-demonstrative_form.label: demonstrative forms
Entity-demonstrative_form.description: Demonstrative forms refer to linguistic expressions in English, such as 'this', 'that', 'these', and 'those', which indicate specific entities in discourse and vary in usage depending on the genre of the text.

Entity-genre.label: genre
Entity-genre.description: In this context, 'genre' refers to the classification of texts based on their stylistic and thematic characteristics, which influences the distribution of demonstrative expressions in English.

Entity-demonstrative_form_and_function.label: demonstrative forms and functions
Entity-demonstrative_form_and_function.description: The term 'demonstrative forms and functions' refers to the various linguistic expressions and their grammatical roles that indicate specific entities in discourse, particularly how their usage varies across different genres of text.

Entity-genre_dependent.label: genre dependent
Entity-genre_dependent.description: The term 'genre dependent' refers to the variability in the distribution and usage of demonstrative expressions across different types of texts or genres.

Entity-function.label: functions
Entity-function.description: In this context, 'functions' refers to the roles and purposes that demonstrative expressions serve in different genres of text.

Entity-a_larger_study_of_anaphoric_expre.label: a larger study of anaphoric expressions
aliases: a larger study of anaphoric expressions
Entity-a_larger_study_of_anaphoric_expre.description: A larger study of anaphoric expressions refers to an extensive research initiative that investigates the use and distribution of anaphoric expressions, including demonstrative forms, across various texts, with the aim of enhancing natural language generation systems.

mentions.local_name: a larger study of anaphoric expressions

Entity-text.label: texts
Entity-text.description: The term 'texts' refers to various written materials and literary works analyzed in the study to investigate the genre-dependent distribution of demonstrative expressions in English.

Entity-demonstrative_expression.label: demonstrative expressions
Entity-demonstrative_expression.description: Demonstrative expressions are linguistic terms that refer to words or phrases used to indicate specific entities in a discourse, typically including terms like 'this', 'that', 'these', and 'those'.

Entity-the_result.label: the results
Entity-the_result.description: The results refer to the findings from a larger study on anaphoric expressions that will be utilized in the development of a natural language generation system.

Entity-study.label: study
Entity-study.description: The 'study' refers to a larger research initiative focused on anaphoric expressions, which aims to analyze their usage and integrate the findings into a natural language generation system.

Entity-discourse_processing_algorithm.label: discourse processing algorithms
Entity-discourse_processing_algorithm.description: Discourse processing algorithms are computational models designed to analyze and interpret the structure and meaning of spoken or written discourse, facilitating understanding of how language is used in context.

Entity-anaphoric_expression.label: anaphoric expressions
Entity-anaphoric_expression.description: Anaphoric expressions are linguistic elements that refer back to previously mentioned entities or concepts within a discourse, serving to maintain coherence and clarity in communication.

Entity-a_broad_range_of_text.label: a broad range of texts
Entity-a_broad_range_of_text.description: A broad range of texts refers to a diverse collection of written works across various genres that are analyzed to understand the contextual usage and distribution of demonstrative expressions in English.

Entity-english.label: English
Entity-english.description: English is a West Germanic language that is the primary language spoken in England and widely used as a global lingua franca.

Entity-natural_language_generation_syste.label: natural language generation system
Entity-natural_language_generation_syste.description: A natural language generation system is a type of software that uses artificial intelligence techniques to automatically produce human-like text based on input data.

Entity-paper.label: paper
Entity-paper.description: A paper is a written document that presents research findings, theories, or arguments, typically in an academic or scholarly context.

Entity-research.label: research
Entity-research.description: Research refers to a systematic investigation or study aimed at discovering and interpreting facts, theories, or principles in a specific field.

summary: This paper presents necessary and sufficient conditions for the use of demonstrative expressions in English and discusses implications for current discourse processing algorithms . We examine a broad range of texts to show how the distribution of demonstrative forms and functions is genre dependent . This research is part of a larger study of anaphoric expressions , the results of which will be incorporated into a natural language generation system .

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, displaying, or providing information about the object. It signifies a communicative act where the subject conveys specific content, findings, or concepts to an audience, thereby establishing a relationship where the subject serves as the source of the information and the object represents the content being shared.

Predicate-discusses.label: discusses
Predicate-discusses.description: The predicate 'discusses' indicates that the subject engages in a detailed examination or conversation about the object, providing insights, analysis, or commentary related to the topic at hand. It implies an exploration of ideas, arguments, or findings that are relevant to the object, facilitating a deeper understanding of the subject matter.

Predicate-used_in.label: used in
Predicate-used_in.description: The predicate 'used in' establishes a relationship where the subject is an entity, concept, or phenomenon that is applied, implemented, or utilized within the context or framework of the object. It indicates that the subject has a functional or practical role in the environment, system, or language represented by the object.

Predicate-is_related_to.label: is related to
Predicate-is_related_to.description: The predicate 'is related to' establishes a connection or association between the subject and the object, indicating that they share a relevant relationship or are linked in some meaningful way. This relationship can encompass various forms of connection, such as conceptual, functional, causal, or contextual ties, suggesting that understanding one may provide insights into the other.

Predicate-show_how_the_distribution_of.label: show how the distribution of
Predicate-show_how_the_distribution_of.description: The predicate 'show how the distribution of' serves to illustrate or explain the patterns, variations, or arrangements of a particular set of elements or phenomena within a specified subject. It connects the subject to the object by indicating that the subject will provide insights or evidence regarding the prevalence, occurrence, or organization of the object in question, thereby facilitating a deeper understanding of the relationship between the two.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or relationship between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject possesses a certain quality, characteristic, or state represented by the object, thereby asserting that the two are connected in a specific way.

Predicate-show_how.label: show how
Predicate-show_how.description: The predicate 'show how' serves to indicate a method or process by which the subject elucidates or demonstrates the nature, characteristics, or dynamics of the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject provides insight or clarification regarding the mechanisms or patterns associated with the object, thereby facilitating understanding of the object's attributes or behaviors.

Predicate-is_part_of.label: is part of
Predicate-is_part_of.description: The predicate 'is part of' indicates a relationship where the subject is a component, element, or subset of the object, which represents a larger whole or context. This connection implies that the subject contributes to or is included within the broader scope defined by the object.

Predicate-will_be_incorporated_into.label: will be incorporated into
Predicate-will_be_incorporated_into.description: The predicate 'will be incorporated into' indicates a future action where the subject is expected to be integrated or included within the framework, structure, or system represented by the object. This suggests a process of assimilation or merging, where the subject contributes to or enhances the capabilities or functionalities of the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset that falls under the wider category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a broader conceptual framework or classification that includes the subject as part of its scope.
